s a fallback (since not all JUnit 4 test classes have

What woul=
d happen if I have:

@Test (expected=3DBar.class)
public void testMyFoo () =
{}

If we execute junit3 style, it will find this test case, but won't see
=
the expected=3D attribute.

That's pretty interesting. I like the formal int=
roduction to JUnit.
How much experience would the typical person taking thi=
s course have?

The docs I have for this assignment are:

An assignment ove=
rview

http://www.contrib.andrew.cmu.edu/~bmaurer/15-211/s06/snake/docs/

A=
n introduction to testing:

http://www.contrib.andrew.cmu.edu/~bmaurer/15-2=
11/s06/snake/docs/testing.html

I think this documentation is coming in to =
the idea of testing from a
different angle than the MIT one: my goal here i=
s to enable people to
understand how JUnit will help them for this assignme=
nt, rather than
to give the background of "what is testing, why do we do it=
, etc".

Just for some fun stats about how people are doing on this assignm=
ent
so far: about 50 people have submitted a solution for the problem so
fa=
r (out of 190 students) -- it is due thursday at midnight (!!!). Of
these p=
eople, about 20 pass the tests for the circular buffer based
queue, about 1=
5 pass them for hash table. Glancing over people's code,
it looks like the =
people who submitted test cases along with their
code are doing much better=
 on the submission system's tests (nb:
students are not allowed to see thei=
r results on all of our test
cases. So they are "blind" in some ways).

We'=
re thinking of some fun ways we can put testing into the course.
For exampl=
e, I was thinking of giving people partial credit for the
assignment if the=
y 1) wrote a patch for their own code and 2) wrote
test cases that caught t=
heir bugs. At dinner last night with another
TA friend, we thought about an=
 assignment where we would give people
.jar files with a broken List/Queue/=
HashSet/whatever and they would
have to 1) figure out what was wrong and 2)=
 write a test case.

It'd be really fun to package an exercise like this an=
d publish it. I
think that many CS courses don't teach people the testing s=
kills they
need.

-- Ben
